chunks.original_text: 喷则大者如珠，小者如雾，杂而下者不可胜数也。 今予动吾天机，而不知其所以然。 蚿谓蛇曰：吾以众足行，而不及子之无足，何也？ 蛇曰：夫天机之所动，何可易邪？ 吾安用足哉！ 蛇谓风曰：予动吾脊胁而行，则有似也。 今子蓬蓬然起於北海，蓬蓬然入於南海，而似无有，何也？ 风曰：然。 予蓬蓬然起於北海而入於#2南海也，然而指我则胜我，鳟践也。 我亦胜我。 虽然，夫折大木，蜚大屋者，唯我能也，故以众小不胜为大胜也。 为大胜者，唯圣人能之。 孔子游於匡，宋人围之数匝，而弦歌不辍。 子路入见，曰：何夫子之娱也？ 孔子曰：来，吾语汝。 我讳穷久矣，而不免，命也； 求通久矣，而不得，时也。 当尧、舜而天下无穷人，非知得也； 当桀、纣而天下无通人，非知失也：时势适然。 夫水行不避蛟龙者，渔父之勇也； 陆行不避兕虎者，猎夫之勇也； 知穷之有命，知通之有时，临大难而不惧者，圣人之勇也。 由，处矣。 吾命有所制矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The spray scatters—some droplets large as pearls, some fine as mist, falling in countless profusion. Now I move by my Heavenly mechanism, yet know not how it comes to be.

The centipede said to the snake: "I walk with many feet, yet cannot match your footless stride—why is this?"
The snake replied: "How can one alter what the Heavenly mechanism sets in motion? What need have I for feet?"

The snake said to the wind: "I move by flexing my spine and ribs—there is something to it. Yet you rise in a great rush from the Northern Sea, rush into the Southern Sea, and seem as if you were nothing at all—why is this?"
The wind said: "Indeed. I rise in a great rush from the Northern Sea and enter the Southern Sea, yet a finger can overpower me, a toe can trample me. I, too, am overpowered by myself. Nevertheless, to snap great trees and topple mighty halls—only I can do this. Thus, to turn many small defeats into a great victory is the greatest victory of all. Only the sage can achieve this."

Confucius was traveling in Kuang when men of Song surrounded him in several rings, yet he continued playing his zither and singing without pause. Zilu entered and said: "Why is the Master so at ease?"
Confucius replied: "Come, let me tell you. I have long sought to avoid adversity, yet cannot escape it—this is fate. I have long sought success, yet cannot attain it—this is timing. In the age of Yao and Shun, there were no men in adversity, not because of their wisdom; in the age of Jie and Zhou, there were no men of success, not because of their folly: the circumstances of the times made it so. The fisherman who travels the waters without fear of dragons and serpents shows courage; the hunter who travels the land without fear of rhinoceroses and tigers shows courage; but to know that adversity is a matter of fate, that success comes with timing, and to face great peril without fear—this is the courage of the sage. You, Zilu, take your place. My fate is governed by something beyond me."

Kui pitied the centipede, the centipede pitied the snake, the snake pitied the wind, the wind pitied the eye, the eye pitied the mind.

Kui said to the centipede: 'I leap and stride with my single foot—nothing compares to me. Now you move with ten thousand feet—how do you manage?'
The centipede said: 'Not so. Have you not seen one who spits?'"

chunks.original_text: 无几何，将甲者进，辞曰：以为阳虎也，故围之； 今非也，请辞而退。 公孙龙问於魏牟曰：龙少学先王之道，长而明仁义之行； 合同异，离坚白； 然不然，可不可； 困百家之知，穷众口之辩：吾自以为至达已。 今吾闻庄子之言，茫焉异之。 不知论之不及与？ 知之弗若与？ 今吾无所开吾喙，敢问其方。 公子牟隐机大息，仰天而笑曰：子独不闻夫埳井之鼃乎？ 谓东海之鳖曰：吾乐与平声。 吾跳梁乎井干音寒之上，入休乎缺甃之崖。 赴水则接掖持颐，蹶泥则没足灭跗。 还虷蟹与科斗，莫吾能若也。 且夫擅一壑之水，而跨跱埳井之乐，此亦至矣。 夫子奚不时来入观乎？ 东海之鳖左足未入，而右膝已絷矣。 於是逡巡而却，告之海曰：夫千里之远，不足以举其大； 千仞之高，不足以极其深。 禹之时，十年九潦，而水弗为加益； 汤之时，八年七旱，而崖不为加损。 夫不为顷久推移，不以多少进退者，此亦东海之大乐也。 於是埳井之鼃闻之，适适然惊往而仓皇之貌，规规然自失也。 且夫知不知是非之竟上声，而犹欲观於庄子之言，是犹使蚊负山，商距驰河，必不胜任矣。 且夫知不知论极妙之言，而自适一时之利者，是非埳井之鼃与？ 且彼方跐黄泉而登大皇，无南无北，奭然四解，沦於不测； 无东无西，始於玄冥，反於大通。 子乃规规然而求之以察，索之以辩，是直用管窥天，用锥指地也，不亦小乎？ 子往矣。 且子独不闻夫寿陵余子之学行於邯郸与？ 未得国能，又失其故行矣，直匍匐而归耳。 今子不去，将忘子之故，失子之业。 公孙龙口呿区遮切，张口也而不合，舌举而不下，乃逸而走。 庄子钓於澲水。 楚王使大夫二人往先焉，曰：愿以竟上声内累矣。 庄子持竿不顾，曰：吾闻楚有神龟，死已三千岁矣。 王巾笥而藏之庙堂之上。 此龟者，宁其死为留骨而贵乎？ 宁其生而曳尾於涂中乎？ 二大夫曰：宁生而曳尾於涂中。 庄子曰：往矣。 吾将曳尾於涂中。 惠子相梁，庄子往见之。 或谓惠子曰：庄子来，欲代子相。 於是惠子恐，搜於国中三日三夜。 庄子往见之，曰：南方有鸟，其名鹓雏，子知之乎？ 夫鹓雏发於南海而飞於北海，非梧桐不止，非练实不食，非醴泉不饮。 於是鸱得腐鼠，鹓雏过之，仰而视之曰：吓。 今子欲以子之梁国而吓我邪？ 庄子与惠子游於濠梁之上。 庄子曰：鲦音条鱼出游从容，是鱼乐也。 惠子曰：子非鱼，安知鱼之乐？ 庄子曰：子非我，安知我不知鱼之乐？ 惠子曰：我非子，固不知子矣； 子固非鱼也，子之不知鱼之乐，全矣。 庄子曰：请循其本。 惠#3子曰：汝安知鱼乐云者，既已知吾知之句而问我句。 我知之濠上也。 惠子曰：如庄子所言，我非子，固不知子矣。 然子固非鱼，则子全然不知鱼之乐矣。 盖我与子犹同是人。 子与鱼，人物殊异，则全然不相知可见矣。 庄子曰：请循其本者。 本来只说鱼乐，因有不知之辨，今且循本来话柄。 子言我不知鱼乐云者，已知吾知之，特故问我耳。 今我与汝言所以知鱼乐者，我知之濠上也。 夫鱼进於濠中，庄子游於濠上。 乐意相关，有不期然而然者，浴乎沂，风乎舞雩之气象也。 南华真经循本卷之十六竟 #1此处有一段重复文字已删。
chunks.translated_text:
Not long after, armored soldiers advanced and declared: "We mistook you for Yang Hu, hence the siege. Now that we see our error, we beg leave to withdraw."

Gongsun Long questioned Wei Mou, saying: "In my youth, I studied the Way of the former kings; in maturity, I mastered the practice of benevolence and righteousness. I harmonized sameness and difference, separated hardness and whiteness; affirmed the untrue, negated the possible—baffling the wisdom of the hundred schools, exhausting the eloquence of all disputants. I took myself for one of perfect understanding. Yet now I hear the words of Zhuangzi, and feel only bewildered estrangement. Do I fall short in debate? Or do I simply lack his depth of insight? Now my beak hangs open—I dare ask: what is the method?"

Prince Mou leaned against his desk, sighed deeply, looked to the heavens, and laughed: "Have you never heard of the frog in the shallow well? It said to the turtle of the Eastern Sea: 'How joyful I am! I leap and prance upon the well’s railing, rest upon the broken bricks of its walls. When I plunge into the water, it supports my armpits and cradles my chin; when I trample the mud, it swallows my feet and ankles. I turn to look at the shrimp, crabs, and tadpoles—none can match me. Moreover, to command the waters of this single ravine and straddle the joys of this shallow well—what more could one desire? Why not come and see for yourself?'

The turtle of the Eastern Sea had not yet set its left foot inside when its right knee was already pinned. It retreated in hesitation and told the sea: 'A distance of a thousand *li* cannot convey its vastness; a height of a thousand *ren* cannot plumb its depths. In the time of Yu, nine years out of ten saw floods, yet the waters did not increase; in the time of Tang, seven years out of eight saw drought, yet the shores did not diminish. Unchanged by the passage of moments or ages, unmoved by the ebb and flow of quantity—this is the great joy of the Eastern Sea.'

When the frog in the shallow well heard this, it was struck dumb with astonishment, its gaze wandering in dismay, utterly lost. Now, if you cannot even discern the bounds of right and wrong, yet still wish to examine Zhuangzi’s words, it is like making a mosquito bear a mountain or a millipede race across a river—surely beyond your strength. And if you grasp not the subtleties of his discourse, yet seek only momentary advantage, are you not the frog in the shallow well?

Moreover, he treads the Yellow Springs and ascends the Great Vast, unbound by south or north, released in all four directions, submerged in the unfathomable; unbound by east or west, beginning in the dark and obscure, returning to the Great Thoroughfare. Yet you would measure him with narrow scrutiny, seek him with argument—is this not like gazing at the sky through a tube or pointing at the earth with an awl? Is it not petty? Begone!

Have you not heard of the young man from Shouling who went to Handan to learn its walk? Before mastering the state’s skill, he forgot his old gait and could only crawl home. If you do not leave now, you will forget your former ways and lose your craft."

Gongsun Long’s mouth gaped open, his tongue lifted and would not descend; he fled in haste.

Zhuangzi was fishing in the Pu River when the King of Chu sent two ministers to approach him first, saying: "I wish to trouble you with the affairs of my realm."

Zhuangzi held his rod and did not turn, saying: "I have heard that in Chu there is a sacred tortoise, dead for three thousand years. The king keeps it wrapped in silk and stored in a casket in his ancestral temple. Would this tortoise rather have died to leave its bones venerated, or lived to drag its tail through the mud?"

The two ministers said: "It would rather live and drag its tail through the mud."

Zhuangzi said: "Go away. I will drag my tail through the mud."

When Huizi was prime minister of Liang, Zhuangzi went to visit him. Someone told Huizi: "Zhuangzi is coming to replace you as minister." Huizi grew alarmed and searched the state for three days and three nights.

Zhuangzi went to see him and said: "In the south there is a bird called the *yuanchu*—do you know it? The *yuanchu* sets out from the Southern Sea and flies to the Northern Sea; it alights only on the *wutong* tree, eats only bamboo fruit, and drinks only sweet spring water. Then a *chi* hawk, clutching a rotten rat, saw the *yuanchu* pass overhead and looked up, crying: '*Ha!*' Now do you mean to frighten me with your state of Liang?"

Zhuangzi and Huizi strolled upon the bridge over the Hao River. Zhuangzi said: "The *tiao* fish swim leisurely—this is the joy of fish."

Huizi said: "You are not a fish—how do you know their joy?"

Zhuangzi said: "You are not me—how do you know I do not know the joy of fish?"

Huizi said: "I am not you, so of course I do not know you; but you are certainly not a fish, so your ignorance of the fish’s joy is complete."

Zhuangzi said: "Let us return to the beginning. When you said, 'How do you know the joy of fish?' you already knew I knew it, yet you asked me. I know it from here, above the Hao."

Huizi said: "As you put it, I am not you, so of course I do not know you. But you are certainly not a fish, so your ignorance of the fish’s joy is complete. That you and I are both human is evident. You and the fish are different kinds—your complete lack of mutual understanding is clear."

Zhuangzi said: "Let us return to the beginning. Originally, we spoke only of the joy of fish, but then came the debate over knowledge. Now, let us follow the original thread. When you said, 'How do you know the joy of fish?' you already knew I knew it, yet you asked me deliberately. Now, as for how I know the joy of fish—I know it from here, above the Hao. The fish advance in the river, and I wander above it. Our joys are linked, an unplanned harmony—like bathing in the Yi or dancing in the wind at the *wuyu*."

chunks.original_text: #2据通行本补『以物害己。 ……北海而入於』一段文字。 #3据通行本此处无『惠』字。 南华真经循本卷之十七 庐陵竹峰罗勉道述门人彭祥点校 外篇至乐 天下有至乐无有哉？ 有可以活身者无有哉？ 今奚为奚据，奚避奚处？ 奚就奚去？ 奚乐奚恶？ 夫天下之所尊者，富贵寿善也； 所乐者，身安厚味美服好色音声也； 所下者，贪贱夭恶也； 所苦者，身不得安逸，口不得厚味，形不得美服，目不得好色，耳不得音声。 若不得者，则大忧以惧，其为形也亦愚哉。 夫富者，苦身疾作，多积财而不得尽用，其为形也亦外矣。 夫贵者，夜以继日，思虑善否，其为形也亦疏矣。 人之生也，与忧俱生。 寿者惛惛音昏，久忧不死，何之苦也。 其为形也亦远矣。 烈士为天下见善矣，未足以活身。 吾未知善之诚善邪？ 诚不善邪？ 若以为善矣，不足活身； 以为不善矣，足以活人故。 曰：忠谏不听，蹲循勿争。 低蹲而顺循之。 故夫子胥争之，以残其形； 不争，名亦不成。 诚有善无有哉？ 今俗之所为与其所乐，吾又未知乐之果乐邪？ 果不乐邪？ 吾观夫俗之所乐，举群趣者， 乐举群趣四字相连。 誙誙音铿然如将不得已，而皆曰乐者，吾未之乐也，亦未知不乐也。 果有乐无有哉？ 吾以无为诚乐矣，又俗之所大苦也。 故曰：至乐无乐，至誉无誉。 天下是非果未可定也。 虽然，无为可以定是非。 至乐活身，唯无为几存。 请尝试言之：天无为以之清，地无为以之宁。 故两无为相合，万物皆化。 芒乎芴乎，而无从出乎？ 芴乎芒乎，而无有象乎？ 万物职职，皆从无为殖。 故曰：天地无为也，而无不为也。 人也孰能得无为哉。 庄子妻死，惠子吊之，庄子则方箕踞鼓盆而歌。 惠子曰：与人居，长子老身死不哭亦足矣，又鼓盆而歌，不亦甚乎。 庄子曰：不然。 是其始，死也，我独何能无槩慨同。 然察其始而本无生； 非徒无生也，而本无形； 非徒无形也，而本无气。 杂乎芒葱之间，变而有气，气变而有形，形变而有生。 今又变而之死。 是相与为春秋冬夏四时行也。 人且偃然寝於巨室，而我噭噭音叫然随而哭之，自以为不通乎命，故止也。 支离叔与滑音骨介叔观於冥伯之丘，昆仑之墟，黄帝之所。 休俄而柳生其左肘，其意蹶蹶然恶之。 支离叔曰：子恶之乎？ 滑介叔曰：亡音无予何恶。 生者，假借也。 假之而生生者，尘垢也。 死生为昼夜。 且吾与子观化而化及我，我又何恶焉。 冥伯，死者之称。 犹《文选》所称冥漠君。 冥伯之丘，死人墓也。 其墓在昆仑之墟。 昆仑者，曾经黄帝之所休息。 昆仑有五城十二楼，神仙所居。 黄帝乃古者得道升仙之帝，感慨追忆言此人居神仙之境，而不能如黄帝学仙以至死也。 柳者，障柩之柳。 《檀弓》：周人墙置翣。 注：墙，柳衣也。 《正义》曰：墙之障柩犹垣墙障家，故谓障柩之物为墙。 墙即柳也。 缝人注：柳，聚也，诸饰所聚。 支离叔与滑介叔观於冥伯之丘墟墓之间，意想所致，倏有障柩之柳出於左手所肘处。 不祥之征，殆将死矣。 故其意蹶蹶然惊动而恶之。 支离叔既恶之，又问滑介叔曰：汝恶之乎？ 介叔曰：无，予何恶之？ 有生者，假借而已。 所谓四大假合是也，既假之而生，则不过如尘垢之集耳。
chunks.translated_text:
**Outer Chapters: Supreme Joy**

Is there in the world a supreme joy, or is there none? Are there means to preserve life, or are there none? What should one do now, and what rely upon? What avoid, and where abide? What pursue, and what forsake? What find joy in, and what detest?

What the world honors are wealth, nobility, long life, and goodness; what it delights in are bodily ease, rich flavors, fine garments, beautiful sights, and sweet sounds. What it despises are poverty, lowliness, early death, and wickedness; what it finds bitter are the body denied comfort, the mouth denied rich flavors, the form denied fine garments, the eyes denied beautiful sights, and the ears denied sweet sounds. If these are not attained, one is gripped by great sorrow and fear—how foolishly this treats the body!

The wealthy exhaust themselves with toil, amassing wealth they cannot fully use—how estranged this is from the body. The noble pass days and nights in ceaseless calculation, weighing good and ill—how distant this is from the body. As for human life, it is born with sorrow. The long-lived grow dull and muddled, enduring long sorrow without death—what agony this is! How far removed from the body!

The steadfast man is praised by the world for his goodness, yet it is not enough to preserve his life. Do I know whether goodness is truly good? Or truly not good? If we deem it good, it is not enough to preserve life; if we deem it not good, it is enough to preserve others. It is said: "When loyal remonstrance is unheeded, crouch low and follow—do not contend." Thus when Wu Zixu contended, his body was destroyed; had he not contended, his name would not have endured. Is there truly goodness, or is there none?

As for what the vulgar do and delight in, do I know whether their joy is truly joy? Or truly not joy? I observe that what the vulgar delight in is the clamor of the crowd, rushing together in a clanging throng as if they cannot help themselves. Yet all call it joy—do I find it joyful? Or do I not? I do not know whether it is truly joy or not. Is there truly joy, or is there none?

I take non-action as true joy, yet this is what the vulgar find most bitter. Thus it is said: "Supreme joy is no joy; supreme praise is no praise." The right and wrong of the world cannot truly be settled. Nevertheless, non-action can settle right and wrong. Supreme joy preserves life—only non-action comes close to this.

Let me try to speak of it: Heaven is clear through non-action; Earth is tranquil through non-action. Thus when the two non-actions combine, the myriad things are transformed. Vague and indistinct, from whence do they emerge? Indistinct and vague, without form do they appear? The ten thousand things, teeming and thriving, all grow from non-action. Thus it is said: "Heaven and Earth act through non-action, yet there is nothing they do not do." Who among men can attain non-action?

When Zhuangzi’s wife died, Huizi came to offer condolences. Zhuangzi was squatting with legs spread, drumming on a basin and singing. Huizi said: "To live with someone, raise a child to adulthood, and grow old together—if upon her death you do not weep, it would be enough. But to drum on a basin and sing—is this not excessive?"

Zhuangzi said: "Not so. When she first died, how could I alone not feel grief? Yet I examined her beginning and found she was originally without life. Not only without life, but originally without form; not only without form, but originally without *qi*. Amidst the vague and indistinct, there was transformation, and *qi* arose; the *qi* transformed and form arose; form transformed and life arose. Now it has transformed again into death. This is like the procession of the four seasons—spring, autumn, winter, summer. She now lies peacefully in the great chamber, and if I were to wail and weep after her, I would consider myself ignorant of fate. Thus I stopped."

Zhilishu and Gujieshu were observing the mound of Mingbo, the ruins of Kunlun, where the Yellow Emperor once dwelled. Suddenly, a willow sprouted from Gujieshu’s left elbow, and he was startled and dismayed. Zhilishu said: "Do you detest it?"

Gujieshu replied: "No—why should I detest it? Life is but a temporary borrowing. What borrows and gives rise to life is but dust and grime. Death and life are like day and night. Moreover, you and I observe transformation, and transformation has reached me—why should I detest it?"

Mingbo is a term for the dead, like the "Lord of the Dark" in the *Wen Xuan*. The mound of Mingbo is a burial ground, located in the ruins of Kunlun. Kunlun has five cities and twelve towers, the abode of immortals. The Yellow Emperor was an ancient ruler who attained the Dao and ascended as an immortal. These words express sorrowful reminiscence: this man dwells in the realm of immortals yet cannot, like the Yellow Emperor, cultivate immortality and thus faces death.

The willow refers to the funeral bier. In the *Tan Gong*, the Zhou people placed *sha* on the walls. The commentary states: "The wall is the *liu* covering." The *Zhengyi* says: "The wall that screens the bier is like a wall screening a house, hence the screening object is called a wall. The wall is the *liu*." The *Feng Ren* commentary: "*Liu* means gathering—the gathering of all adornments." Zhilishu and Gujieshu were observing among the mounds and ruins of the burial ground when, by the power of their thoughts, a willow for screening the bier suddenly sprouted from Gujieshu’s left elbow. An ominous sign—he was about to die. Thus he was startled and dismayed.

Zhilishu, though dismayed, asked Gujieshu: "Do you detest it?" Gujieshu replied: "No—why should I detest it? What has life is but a temporary borrowing. This is what is meant by the four great elements provisionally combining. Since it is but a borrowing that gives rise to life, it is no more than dust and grime gathering together."

chunks.original_text: 何足控搏？ 遂言死生犹昼夜，乃理之常，不足惊惧。 生者假借也，又是论人生死之生不又粘上，生其左肘之生字。 且吾与子观化而化及於我。 化，死也。 孟子曰：比化者无使土亲肤，言吾与子适墓观人之死，而睹此不祥死将及於我。 人有死则我亦必有死，我又何恶焉？ 或以柳为杨柳，殊与此章文义不相贯。 庄子之楚，见空髑音独髅音楼，髐苦尧切然有形。 檄音叫以马捶，因而问之，曰：夫子贪生失理而为此乎？ 将子有亡国之事、斧钺之诛而为此乎？ 将子有不善之行，愧遗父母妻子之丑而为此乎？ 将子有冻馁之患而为此乎？ 将子之春秋故及此乎？ 於是语卒，援髑髅，枕去声而卧。 夜半，髑髅见梦曰：子之谈者似辩士，视#1子所言，皆生人之累也，死则无此矣。 子欲闻死之说乎？ 庄子曰：然。 髑髅曰：死，无君於上，无臣於下，亦无四时之事，从然以天地为春秋，虽南面王乐，不能过也。 庄子不信，曰：吾使司命复生子形，为子骨肉肌肤，反子父母、妻子、闾里、知识，子欲之乎？ 髑髅深膑蹙頞曰：吾安能弃南面王乐而复为人间之劳乎。 颜渊东之齐，孔子有忧色。 子贡下席而问曰：小子敢问，回东之齐，夫子有忧色，何邪？ 孔子曰：善哉汝问。 昔者管子有言，丘甚善之，曰：褚小者不可以怀大，绠短者不可以汲深。 夫若是者，以为命有所成而形有所适也，夫不可损益。 吾恐回与齐侯言尧、舜、黄帝之道而重以燧人、神农之言。 彼将内求於已而不得，不得则惑，人惑则死。 且汝独不闻邪？ 昔者海鸟止於鲁郊，鲁侯御音迓，而觞之于庙，奏九韶以为乐，具大牢以为膳。 鸟乃眩视忧悲，不敢食一脔，不敢饮一杯，三日而死。 此以己养养鸟也，非以鸟养养鸟也。 夫以鸟养鸟者，宜栖之深林，游之坛陆，浮之江湖，食之鳅，随行列而止，委蛇而处。 彼唯人言之恶闻，奚以夫譊譊音呶为乎？ 咸池九韶之乐，张之洞庭之野，鸟闻之而飞，兽闻之而走，鱼闻之而下入，人卒闻之，相与还而观之。 鱼处水而生，人处水而死。 彼必相与异，其好恶故异也。 故先圣不一其能，不同其事。 名止於实，义设於适，是之谓条达而福持。 列子行句，食於道。 从 《列子》从字下有者字，指字下有顾。 谓弟子，百丰字曰。 #2

"Why cling or struggle? Thus he spoke: life and death are but day and night—this is the constant principle of the Dao, not worth alarm or dread. Life is but a temporary borrowing, and in this discourse on human life and death, the character for 'life' (*sheng*) does not again adhere to the earlier instance—here, it refers to the 'growth' (*sheng*) on his left elbow. Moreover, you and I observe transformation, and transformation has now reached us. Transformation means death.

Mencius said: *'Among those who face transformation, let no soil cling to the skin.'* This means that you and I came to the burial grounds to observe others' deaths, yet witnessed this ominous sign—death was about to reach us. If all men must die, then I too must die. Why should I detest it?"

Some mistakenly take *liu* (柳) to mean the willow tree, but this misinterprets the passage’s meaning.

When Zhuangzi traveled to Chu, he saw an empty skull, bleached and still retaining form. He struck it with his horsewhip and questioned it: "Did you, sir, covet life and lose the Way, bringing this upon yourself? Or did you suffer the fall of a state or the execution of the axe? Or did you commit some shameful deed, bringing disgrace upon your parents, wife, and children? Or did you endure the miseries of cold and hunger? Or did your years simply come to this end?"

Having finished speaking, he took the skull as a pillow and lay down. At midnight, the skull appeared in a dream and said: "Your words resemble those of a sophist. All you have spoken of are the burdens of the living—death knows none of these. Would you hear the truth of death?"

Zhuangzi said: "Yes."

The skull replied: "In death, there is no ruler above nor minister below, nor the affairs of the four seasons. At ease, one takes heaven and earth as spring and autumn. Even the joy of a king facing south cannot surpass it."

Zhuangzi, unconvinced, said: "If I had the Controller of Fate restore your form, giving you bones, flesh, and skin, and returning you to your parents, wife, children, neighbors, and acquaintances—would you desire this?"

The skull frowned deeply and said: "How could I abandon the joy of a king facing south to return to the toils of the human world?"

When Yan Hui traveled east to Qi, Confucius wore a troubled expression. Zigong rose from his mat and asked: "May I dare ask why, when Yan Hui went east to Qi, you bear such a worried look?"

Confucius replied: "Excellent question. Long ago, Guanzi spoke words I deeply admired: *'A small sack cannot hold a large object; a short rope cannot draw from the deep.'* Such is the way of fate—it has its completion, and form has its proper place. Neither can be diminished or augmented. I fear that Yan Hui will speak to the Marquis of Qi of the Ways of Yao, Shun, and the Yellow Emperor, and further cite the words of Suiren and Shennong. The marquis will search within himself and find nothing, and finding nothing, he will be perplexed. Perplexity in a man leads to death.

Have you not heard the tale? Once, a seabird alighted in the outskirts of Lu. The Lord of Lu received it with ceremony, feasted it in the ancestral temple, performed the *Nine Shao* as music, and prepared a grand sacrifice as its meal. The bird, however, grew dazed and sorrowful, dared not eat a single morsel, nor drink a single cup, and died after three days. This was nourishing the bird as one nourishes oneself, not as a bird ought to be nourished. To nourish a bird as a bird, one should let it roost in deep forests, roam open plains, float upon rivers and lakes, feed on minnows and eels, follow its flock in flight, and rest at ease. It detests the clamor of human speech—why subject it to such clamor?

When the music of *Xianchi* and *Nine Shao* was played in the wilds of Dongting, birds heard it and flew away, beasts heard it and fled, fish heard it and dove deep, while men, upon hearing it, gathered to listen. Fish live in water and thrive, yet men drown in it. Their natures differ, and so do their likes and dislikes. Thus the sages of old did not impose a single standard of ability nor demand uniformity in affairs. Names were confined to reality, and principles were set according to what was fitting—this is called 'orderly coherence and sustained good fortune.'"

chunks.original_text: 见百岁髑髅，攓蓬而指之曰：唯予与汝知而未尝死、未尝生也。 若果养乎《列子》作过养？ 予果欢乎？ 种有几，得水则为当作□，与绝同，得水土之际则为龟蠙之衣，生於陵屯徒魂切则为陵舄，陵舄得郁栖则为乌足，乌足之根为蛴螬，其叶为胡蝶。 胡蝶胥也化而为虫，生於灶下，其状若脱，其名为鸲掇。 鸲掇千日为鸟，其名为乾余骨。 乾余骨之沫为斯弥，斯弥为食酰。 颐辂生乎食酰，黄軦生乎九猷，瞀芮生乎腐蠸，羊奚比乎不筍，久竹生青宁，青宁生程，程生马，马生人，人又反入於机。 万物皆出於机，皆入於机。 生则有待於养，死则无累，故惧。 以为汝未尝死，我未尝生，则安知汝不为养而我不为欢乎。 种有几以下不可尽晓，姑摭其可解者。 □，古文绝字。 地至於水则绝矣，而亦有物生焉。 得水土交接之际则为鼃蠙之衣。 鼃蠙之衣水舄也，生於水者为水舄，即《诗》所谓言采其藚鼃与蚌。 依，其下以为衣焉。 生於陵屯则为陵舄，即《诗》所谓芣苡，俗云车前草。 一物而有水陆之异也。 食酰，蠛蠓也。 青宁，竹根虫也。 万载有老人言：曾见一虫可五寸长，其后尚有寸许，是竹根未变得，非所谓青宁者乎？ 余寓安乡，亲见灯下一白蛾投灯，忽尾后一个复一个，非出孕育，乃是虚空幻化。 又见洞庭湖中有明山，山顶有禹庙，山崦多人家。 每岁季春，□鹑充斥庙宇及人家，以竹帚朴取，腌以为酢。 商人先期予直，及期征收，有未变尚存一半。 鼠形者，即《月令》所谓田鼠化为鴽也。 以此观天地间变化何限，未可以耳目所不及疑之。 马生人，人又反入於机。 何异释氏轮回之说。 但释氏说得拘，谓生前作恶则死后或变为狗马，业尽又变为人。 有何证据？ 庄子却说得活，万物皆出於机，皆入於机。 夫机者，气之动处。 出於机者，生也入。 於机者，死也。 盈天地间只是阴阳二气，化生万物，死则阳气归天阴气归地。 此气不出天地间，明日复生，人物仍前，只是阴阳二气为之。 但不可把已死之马为方生之人，已死之人为方生之马耳。 《朱子语录》：张横渠说：形溃反原以为人。 生得此个物事，既死此个物事却复归大原。 本去又别从裹面抽出来，生人最为明白。 若如释氏说，则天地间须分几万万团气，各自轮回生灭，缠来缠去，何有了期，成□造化。 《笔谈》云：延州人至今谓虎豹为程，盖言虫也。 南华真经循本卷十七意 #1原文为『诸』，据通行本改为『视』。
chunks.translated_text:
Upon seeing a century-old skull, he plucked a stalk of mugwort and pointed at it, saying: "Only you and I know that you have never died, nor have I ever been born. Are you truly nourished? Am I truly joyful? Seeds contain *qi*—when they encounter water, they become *jue* (絶); at the border of water and soil, they become the raiment of frogs and clams. Born on mounds, they become *lingxi* (陵舄); when *lingxi* finds damp shade, it becomes *wuzu* (乌足); the root of *wuzu* becomes *qicao* (蛴螬), while its leaves become butterflies. Butterflies, in turn, transform into insects, born beneath the hearth, their form like a cast-off skin, named *quduo* (鸲掇). After a thousand days, *quduo* becomes a bird called *ganyugu* (乾余骨). The foam of *ganyugu* becomes *simi* (斯弥), and *simi* becomes *shixi* (食酰). *Yilu* (颐辂) arises from *shixi*, *huangkuang* (黄軦) from *jiuyou* (九猷), *maorui* (瞀芮) from rotten grubs, *yangxi* (羊奚) from withered bamboo, old bamboo gives birth to *qingning* (青宁), *qingning* to *cheng* (程), *cheng* to horses, horses to humans—and humans, in turn, return to the *mechanism*. All things emerge from the *mechanism* and return to the *mechanism*. In life, they depend on nourishment; in death, they bear no burden—yet still, we fear. If you have never died and I have never been born, how can we know that you are not nourished or that I am not joyful?

(For the passage beginning "Seeds contain *qi*," the meaning is not entirely clear; here, only what can be understood is excerpted. *Jue* (□) is the ancient form of *jue* (絶). When earth reaches water, it is cut off—yet even there, things are born. At the intersection of water and soil, they become the raiment of frogs and clams. The raiment of frogs and clams is *shuixi* (水舄), the aquatic variety—what the *Book of Songs* calls "gathering the *xu* (藚)," referring to frogs and clams, which use it as their covering. Born on mounds, it becomes *lingxi* (陵舄), what the *Book of Songs* calls *fuyi* (芣苡), commonly known as *cheqian* grass. The same thing takes different forms in water and on land. *Shixi* (食酰) is the midge. *Qingning* (青宁) is the bamboo-root grub. An old man once said he saw a worm over five inches long, with another inch or so still attached—was this not the bamboo-root grub before its transformation, the so-called *qingning*? While staying in Anxiang, I saw a white moth fly into a lamp, and suddenly, one after another appeared behind it—not from birth, but from empty transformation. I also saw in Dongting Lake a mountain called Mingshan, its peak crowned with Yu’s Temple and many households. Every late spring, *quchun* (□鹑) swarm the temple and homes, swept up with bamboo brooms and pickled into vinegar. Merchants pay in advance, and at harvest, some remain half-transformed, still resembling mice—this is what the *Monthly Ordinances* calls "field mice turning into *ru* (鴽)." Observing this, how can one doubt the boundless transformations of heaven and earth simply because they lie beyond our senses?

Horses give birth to humans, and humans return to the *mechanism*—how is this different from the Buddhist doctrine of reincarnation? Yet the Buddhist account is rigid: if one did evil in a past life, one may be reborn as a dog or horse, and only after exhausting one’s karma does one return to human form. What evidence supports this? Zhuangzi’s version is more fluid: all things emerge from the *mechanism* and return to the *mechanism*. The *mechanism* is where *qi* moves. To emerge from it is birth; to return to it is death. Between heaven and earth, there is only *yin* and *yang qi*, which generate the myriad things. In death, *yang qi* returns to heaven and *yin qi* to earth—yet this *qi* never leaves the realm of heaven and earth. Tomorrow, it will generate things anew, just as before, for it is merely *yin* and *yang qi* at work. One must not mistake a dead horse for a living person, or a dead person for a living horse.

From *Master Zhu’s Recorded Sayings*: Zhang Hengqu said, "When form dissolves, it returns to the origin to become human again. The thing we receive at birth, upon death, returns to the great origin. Then, from within, it is drawn out anew—this is most evident in human birth. If we followed the Buddhist account, heaven and earth would have to contain countless separate clusters of *qi*, each cycling through birth and death, entangled without end—how could this align with the workings of creation?"

From the *Brush Notes*: The people of Yanzhou still call tigers and leopards *cheng* (程), meaning "worm." *The Authentic Scripture of Southern Florescence*, following the original text of Chapter Seventeen (the character *zhu* (诸) was emended to *shi* (视) in common editions).

chunks.original_text: #2应在下文『指之曰下』。 南华真经循本卷之十八 庐陵竹峰罗勉道述门人彭祥点校 外篇达生 达生之情者，不务生之所无以为； 无以为，犹《论语》曰：无以为也。 言无用如此。 达命之情者，不务知之所无奈何。 养形者必先之物，物有余而形不养者有之矣。 有生必先无离形，形不离而生亡者有之矣。 生之来不能却，其去不能止。 悲夫。 世之人以为养形足以存生，而养形果不足以存生，则世奚足为哉。 虽不足为而不可不为者，其为不兔矣。 不免於有形也。 夫欲免为形者，莫如弃世。 弃世则无累，无累则正平，正平则与彼更生， 彼，造物也。 造物生我必有死，我又能存此生，是与造物更相而生。 更生则几矣。 事奚足弃而生奚足遗？ 弃事则形不劳，遗生则精不亏。 夫形全精复，与天为一。 天地，万物之父母也。 合则成体，散则成始。 形精不亏，是谓能移。 精而又精，反以相天。 天，吋韵汀。 移，即上文更字。 言能与之更移也。 有生本具此精，役役世事几失之。 今能更生则又具此精矣，与我此生者，天也。 我又能与天存此生，是相天也。 子列子问关尹曰：至人潜行不窒，蹈火不热，行乎万物之上而不栗。 请问何以至於此？ 关尹曰：是纯气之守也，非知巧果敢之列。 居，吾语汝。 凡有貌象声色者，皆物也，物与物何以相远。 夫奚足以至乎先？ 是色而已。 先，犹超也。 上文：貌象声色，只一色字包括之。 则物之造乎不形，而止乎无所化。 夫得是而穷之者，物焉得而止焉。 彼将处乎不淫之度，而藏乎无端之纪，游乎万物之所终始。 壹其性，养其气，合其德，以通乎物之所造。 夫若是者，其天守全，其神无却音隙，物奚自入焉。 夫醉者之坠车，虽疾不死。 骨节与人同而犯害与人异，其神全也。 乘亦不知也，坠亦不知也，死生惊惧不入乎其胸中，是故运触也物而不慑。 彼得全於酒而犹若是，而况得全於天乎？ 圣人藏於天，故莫之能伤也。 复雠者，不折镆干； 虽有忮心者，不怨飘瓦，是以天下平均。 故无攻战之乱，无杀戮之刑者，由此道也。 不开人之天，而开天之天。 开天者德生，开人者贼生。 不厌其天，不忽於人，民几乎以其真。 仲尼适楚，出於林中，见痀偻者承蜩，犹掇之也。 仲尼曰：子巧乎，有道邪？ 曰：我有道也。 五六月累丸二而不坠，则失者锱铢； 累三而不坠，则失者十一； 累五而不坠，犹掇之也。 吾处身也，若厥株拘杙也； 吾执臂也，若槁木之枝。 虽天地之大，万物之多，而唯蜩翼之知。 吾不反不侧，不以万物易蜩之翼，何为而不得。 孔子顾谓弟子曰：用志不分，乃疑於神。 蜀本作疑，下文亦云：器之所以疑神者，其是与俗作凝。 其痀偻丈人之谓乎。 颜渊问仲尼曰：吾尝济乎觞深之渊，津人操舟若神。 吾问焉曰：操舟可学邪？ 曰：可。 善游者数能。 若乃夫没善涸者也人，则未尝见舟而便操之也。 吾问焉而不吾告，敢问何谓也？ 仲尼曰：善游者数能，忘水也； 若乃夫没人之未尝见舟而便操之也。 彼是#1渊若陵，视舟之覆，犹其车却也。 覆却万方陈乎前而不得入其舍，恶往而不暇。 以瓦注投也者巧，以钩注者惮，以黄金注者殙音昏。 其巧一也，而有所矜，则重外也。 凡外重者内拙。 舍指心而言。

**From the Eighteenth Scroll of the *Authentic Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Following the Original Text**
*(Recorded by Lu Ling’s Bamboo Peak Scholar Luo Miandao; collated by his disciple Peng Xiang)*

**Outer Chapters: "Attaining Life"**

One who attains the essence of life does not strive for what is not essential to life.
*"Not essential"*—as in the *Analects*: "There is no need for this."
This speaks of such uselessness.

One who attains the essence of fate does not strive for what knowledge cannot alter.

To nourish the form, one must first attend to external things—yet there are cases where things are abundant while the form remains unnourished.
Life necessarily begins with form inseparable—yet there are cases where form remains intact while life perishes.
Life’s coming cannot be refused; its going cannot be halted.
How lamentable!

The world believes that nourishing the form suffices to preserve life—yet if nourishing the form truly does not suffice to preserve life, then what in this world is worth doing?
Though it may not suffice, one cannot but do it—such is the inescapable burden.
One cannot escape having form.

To escape the burden of form, nothing surpasses abandoning the world.
Abandoning the world means freedom from entanglements; freedom from entanglements means true equilibrium; true equilibrium means alternating renewal with that which gives life.
*That*—the Creator.
The Creator gives me life, which must end in death—yet if I can preserve this life, I alternate renewal with the Creator.
In such alternation lies the subtlest essence.

Why abandon affairs? Why forsake life?
Abandoning affairs spares the form from labor; forsaking life preserves the essence from depletion.
When form is whole and essence restored, one becomes one with Heaven.
Heaven and Earth are the parents of the myriad things:
United, they form a body; dispersed, they become a beginning.
When form and essence remain undiminished, this is called *shifting*.
Essence refined to its utmost returns to assist Heaven.
*Heaven*—here rhyming with *tian*.
*Shifting*—referring to the "alternation" above.
This means one can alternate with it.

Life originally possesses this essence, yet worldly affairs nearly exhaust it.
Now, by alternating renewal, one regains this essence—what gave me this life was Heaven.
If I, in turn, can preserve this life with Heaven, this is *assisting Heaven*.

Zi Liezi asked Guan Yin: "The perfected person walks underwater without obstruction, treads fire without heat, moves above the myriad things without fear. How does one reach such a state?"
Guan Yin replied: "This is the preservation of pure *qi*, not the realm of cunning, skill, or boldness. Sit, and I will tell you:
All things with appearance, form, sound, or color are merely *things*—how can one thing surpass another?
What suffices to transcend them? Only *formlessness*.
Formlessness is the origin of creation and the end of transformation.
One who attains this and exhausts it—how can mere things constrain them?
They dwell within the measure of restraint, conceal themselves in the traceless principle, and roam through the beginning and end of the myriad things.
Unifying their nature, nurturing their *qi*, harmonizing their virtue, they commune with the source of all things.
Such a one’s Heavenly endowment remains whole, their spirit unbroken—how could things intrude?

The drunken man who falls from a cart, though swiftly, does not die.
His bones and joints are the same as others’, yet the harm he suffers differs—his spirit remains whole.
He neither knows he is riding nor knows he has fallen; life and death, terror and dread do not enter his breast.
Thus, though he collides with things, he is not afraid.
If one preserved by wine can be thus, how much more one preserved by Heaven?
The sage hides within Heaven—thus nothing can harm them.

The avenger does not break the sword’s edge;
Even one with a vengeful heart does not resent a fallen tile—thus the world attains balance.
Therefore, there are no wars of conquest, no punishments of slaughter—this is the Way’s doing.
Do not open the Heavenly in man, but open the Heavenly of Heaven.
Opening Heaven’s Heaven gives birth to virtue; opening man’s Heaven harms life.
Do not reject one’s Heavenly nature, nor neglect the human—then the people approach their true essence."

Confucius traveled to Chu and, passing through a forest, saw a hunchbacked man catching cicadas as if plucking them.
Confucius said: "You are skillful—do you have a method?"
The man replied: "I do. After five or six months of stacking pellets without dropping them, I lose only a fraction; with three pellets, I lose one in ten; with five, it is as if plucking them.
When I steady my body, it is like a withered stump; when I extend my arm, it is like a dead branch.
Though Heaven and Earth are vast and the myriad things many, I am aware only of the cicada’s wings.
I do not turn aside, nor do I let the myriad things distract me from the cicada’s wings—how could I fail?"

Confucius turned to his disciples and said: "Where intent is undivided, it approaches the divine."
*(The Shu edition reads "approaches" (*yi*), and below it says: "The vessel’s divinity lies in its concentration (*ning*)—is this not the hunchbacked elder’s meaning?")*

Yan Yuan asked Confucius: "Once, when I crossed the deep rapids of Shang, the ferryman handled the boat as if by magic. I asked him: ‘Can one learn to handle a boat?’ He said: ‘Yes. A skilled swimmer can learn quickly. As for those who dive and excel in the depths—even if they’ve never seen a boat, they can handle it immediately.’ I asked him, but he did not explain. May I ask what this means?"
Confucius said: "A skilled swimmer can learn quickly because they have forgotten the water. As for those who dive and excel in the depths—even if they’ve never seen a boat, they can handle it immediately because to them, deep pools are like hills, and a capsized boat is like a cart rolling backward.
Ten thousand dangers may lie before them, yet none enter their dwelling—where could they not be at ease?
One who stakes tiles in a game plays skillfully; one who stakes hooks hesitates; one who stakes gold grows confused.
Their skill is the same, yet when they fixate on the stake, they value externals.
All who value externals are clumsy within.
*(Here, the text shifts from the heart to the finger.)*"

chunks.original_text: 田开之见周威公，威公曰：吾闻祝肾学生，吾子与祝肾游，亦何闻焉？ 田开之曰：开之操拔篲扫帚也以侍门庭，亦何闻於夫子。 威公曰：田子无让，寡人愿闻之。 开之曰：闻之夫子曰：善养生者，若牧羊然，视其后者而鞭之。 威公曰：何谓也？ 田开之曰：鲁有单豹者，岩居而水饮，不与民共利，行年七十而犹有婴儿之色，不幸遇饿虎，饿虎杀而食之。 有张毅者，高门县薄，无不走也，行年四十而有内热之病以死。 豹养其内而虎食其外，毅养其外而病攻其内。 此二子者，皆不鞭其后者也。 羊已前行者，不须鞭。 唯鞭其在后者，以喻既养其内者不必更用工於内，但当养其外； 既养其外者不必更用工於外，但当养其内。 仲尼曰：无入而藏，无出而阳，柴立乎其中央。 三者若得，其名必极。 柴立者，如槁木之立也。 柴立乎其中央者，不出不入也。 夫畏涂者，十杀一人，则父子兄弟相戒也，必盛卒徒而后敢出焉，不亦知乎。 人之所取畏者，衽席之上，饮食之间，而不知为之戒者，过也。 祝宗人玄端以临牢策说彘，曰：汝奚恶死？ 吾将三月汝，十日戒，三日斋，藉白茅，加汝肩尻乎雕俎之上，则汝为之乎？ 为彘谋曰：不如食以糠糟而错之牢策之中。 自为谋，则苟生有轩冕之荣，死得於腞音篆盾之上、聚偻 之中则为之。 为负谋则去之，自为谋则取之，所异彘者何也。 腞盾，画盾也。 诗蒙伐有菀谓：画雉羽之文於盾上。 聚偻，曲薄所以卷聚物者。 桓公田於法泽，管仲御，见鬼焉。 公抚管仲之手曰：仲父何见？ 对曰：臣无所见。
chunks.translated_text:
Field Kai met Duke Wei of Zhou, who said: "I have heard that Zhu Shen studied the art of life-nurturing. You, sir, have traveled with Zhu Shen—what have you learned from him?"

Field Kai replied: "I merely wield broom and dustpan to tend the gates and courtyards. What could I have learned from the Master?"

Duke Wei said: "Do not decline, Master Tian. I wish to hear it."

Kai said: "I heard the Master say: 'One who nurtures life well is like a shepherd herding sheep—he watches those lagging behind and whips them.'"

Duke Wei asked: "What does this mean?"

Field Kai said: "In Lu there was Shan Bao, who dwelled in the cliffs and drank from streams, sharing no profit with the people. At seventy, his complexion remained like a child’s. Unluckily, he met a starving tiger, which killed and devoured him. There was also Zhang Yi, who frequented every high gate and thin curtain, running wherever he was called. At forty, he died of internal heat-illness. Bao nurtured his inner self, yet the tiger consumed his outer; Yi nurtured his outer self, yet illness attacked his inner. These two men both failed to whip the laggards.

When sheep have already moved forward, they need no whip. Only those falling behind require it—this illustrates that one who has already nurtured the inner need not labor further within, but should tend the outer; one who has already nurtured the outer need not labor further without, but should tend the inner.

Confucius said: 'Do not withdraw to hide, do not emerge to display, stand like firewood in the center.' If these three are attained, one’s name will surely reach its peak. 'Stand like firewood' means to stand like withered wood. 'Stand like firewood in the center' means neither to emerge nor withdraw.

Those who fear the roads—if one in ten is killed, fathers and sons, brothers and kin will warn one another, mustering armed retinues before daring to venture out. Is this not wisdom? Yet what people truly should fear lies in their bedding and at their meals, yet they fail to guard against it—this is their error.

The sacrificial officer, clad in dark robes, approaches the pen to address the pig, saying: 'Why do you hate death? I will fatten you for three months, purify you for ten days, fast for three, spread white couch-grass, and place your shoulder and rump upon the carved platter—would you accept this?' For the pig’s sake, he would say: 'Better to eat chaff and糟 and be left in the pen.' For his own sake, he would accept a life of noble carriages and caps, and a death upon painted shields and among heaped boughs. For the pig, he rejects it; for himself, he accepts it—how does he differ from the pig?

Painted shields bear the design of pheasant feathers. Heaped boughs are woven mats for gathering things.

Duke Huan was hunting in Fa Marsh, with Guan Zhong driving his chariot, when he saw a ghost. The Duke grasped Guan Zhong’s hand and asked: 'What do you see, Father Zhong?'

He replied: 'Your servant sees nothing.'"

chunks.original_text: 公反，诶於代切请吐代切为病，数曰不出。 齐士有皇子告敖者，曰：公则自伤，鬼乌能伤公。 夫忿滀之气，散而不反，则不为不足； 上而不下，则使人善怒； 下而不上，则使人善忘； 中去声身当心，则为病。 桓公曰：然则有鬼乎？ 曰：有。 沈有履。 灶有髻。 户内之烦壤，雷霆处之； 东北方之下者倍阿，鲑聋蠪跃之； 西北方之下者，则泆阳处之。 水有罔象，丘有山辛，山有夔，野有彷徨，泽有委蛇。 公曰：请问委蛇之状何如？ 皇子曰：委蛇，其大如毂，其长如辕，紫衣而朱冠。 其为物也恶，闻雷车之声则捧其首而立。 见之者殆乎霸。 桓公冁敕引切然而笑曰：此寡人之所见者也。 於是正衣冠与之坐，不终曰而不知病之去也。 蠪，音蠪，赤驳蚍蜉也。 纪渻子为王养斗鸡。 十曰而问：鸡已乎？ 曰：未也，方虚憍音骄而恃气。 十曰又问，曰：未也，犹应向音响景音影。 十曰又问，曰：未也，犹疾视而盛气。 十曰又问，曰：几矣，鸡虽有鸣者，已无变矣，望之似木鸡矣。 其德全矣。 异鸡无敢应者，反走矣。
chunks.translated_text:
Duke Huan returned, choked with rage and fell ill, repeatedly refusing to leave his chamber. Among the Qi scholars was one named Huangzi Gao’ao, who said: "The Duke has harmed himself; how could a ghost harm him? When the qi of pent-up fury scatters and fails to return, it leads to deficiency. If it rises but does not descend, it makes one prone to anger. If it sinks but does not ascend, it makes one prone to forgetfulness. If it departs the center and lodges in the heart, it causes illness."

Duke Huan asked: "Then do ghosts exist?"
He replied: "They do. In the depths lurks *Lü*. The hearth harbors *Ji*. In the dusty corners within doors, *Leiting* dwells. Beneath the northeast lies *Bei’e*, where *Xielong* and *Longyue* leap. Beneath the northwest, *Yiyang* resides. In waters abides *Wangxiang*; in mounds, *Shanxin*; in mountains, *Kui*; in the wilds, *Panghuang*; in marshes, *Weiyi*."

The Duke asked: "What is the form of *Weiyi* like?"
Huangzi said: "*Weiyi* is as large as a wheel hub, as long as a chariot shaft, clad in purple robes and a vermilion cap. As a creature, it is fearsome—when it hears the rumble of thunder-chariots, it clasps its head and stands upright. Whoever sees it is near to attaining hegemony."

Duke Huan burst into laughter and said: "This is what I saw!" Thereupon, he straightened his robes and cap, sat with Huangzi, and before the day was out, his illness had vanished.

---

Jingshengzi reared fighting cocks for the king. After ten days, the king asked: "Are the cocks ready?"
He replied: "Not yet. They are still hollow and arrogant, relying on their qi."
After another ten days, the king asked again.
He replied: "Not yet. They still react to shadows and echoes."
After another ten days, the king asked again.
He replied: "Not yet. They still glare fiercely and bristle with qi."
After another ten days, the king asked again.
He said: "Nearly so. Though other cocks may crow, these remain unchanged—from a distance, they seem like wooden cocks. Their virtue is complete. No other cock dares respond; they turn and flee."

chunks.original_text: 孔子观於吕梁，县音玄水三十仞，流沬四十里，鼋鼉鱼鳖之所不能游也。 见一丈夫游之，以为有苦而欲死也。 使弟子并傍去流而拯之。 数百步而出，被发行歌而游於塘下。 孔子从而问焉，曰：吾以子为鬼，察子则人也。 请问蹈水有道乎？ 曰：亡音无吾无道。 吾始乎故，长乎性，成乎命。 与齐俱入，与汨俱出，从水之道而不为私焉。 此吾所以蹈之也。 孔子曰：何谓始乎故，长乎性，成乎命？ 曰：吾生於陵而安於陵，故也； 长於水而安於水，性也； 不知吾所以然而然，命也。 齐，读与脐。 同《左传》噬齐亦作齐，水漩入处如脐也，汩水滚出处。 梓庆削木为鐻，鐻成，见者惊犹鬼神。 鲁候见而问焉，曰：子何术以为焉？
chunks.translated_text:
Confucius observed the Lü Liang falls, where the water plunged from a height of thirty *ren*, its rapids surging for forty *li*, a place where even soft-shelled turtles, alligators, fish, and turtles could not swim. He saw a man swimming there and thought he must be in distress, seeking death. He sent his disciples to follow the current and rescue him. After several hundred paces, the man emerged, his hair unbound, walking and singing as he strolled beneath the embankment. Confucius followed and questioned him, saying: "I took you for a ghost, but upon closer inspection, you are a man. May I ask if there is a Dao to treading water?"

The man replied: "I have no Dao. I began with what was familiar, grew with my nature, and completed it through fate. I enter with the swirl and emerge with the surge, following the water’s Way without imposing my own will. This is how I tread it."

Confucius said: "What do you mean by beginning with what was familiar, growing with your nature, and completing it through fate?"

The man replied: "I was born on the hills and am at ease on the hills—this is what is familiar. I grew up in the water and am at ease in the water—this is my nature. I do not know why I am as I am, yet I am so—this is fate."

*Qi* (齐) is read as *navel*; as in the *Zuozhuan*, where "噬齐" is also written as "齐," referring to the swirling water’s entry point resembling a navel, while *gǔ* (汩) is where the water surges forth.

Ziqing carved wood into a *jù*, and when it was finished, those who saw it marveled as if it were the work of ghosts or spirits. The Lord of Lu saw it and asked him: "What technique did you use to create this?"

chunks.original_text: 对曰：臣，工人，何术之有。 虽然，有一焉； 臣将为鐻，未尝敢以耗气也，必齐音斋以静心。 齐三日，而不敢怀庆赏爵禄； 齐五日，不敢怀非誉巧拙； 齐七日，辄然忘吾有四枝形体也。 当是时也，无公朝。 其巧专而外滑消，然后入山林，观天性形躯，至矣，然后成见音现鐻，然后加手焉，不然则已。 则以天合天，器之所以疑神者，其谓是与。 鐻，钟鼓之柎。 东野稷以御见庄公，进退中绳，左右旋中规。 庄公以为文 所画规矩之文。 弗过也。 使之钩曲搏也百而反。 颜阖遇之，入见曰：稷之马将败。 公密 不欲彰露也。
chunks.translated_text:
The craftsman replied: "I am but a workman—what technique could I possess? Yet there is one thing: when I set out to carve a *jù*, I never dare to waste my *qi*. I must fast in purity and still my mind. After three days of fasting, I no longer dare entertain thoughts of rewards, ranks, or emoluments. After five days, I no longer dare entertain thoughts of praise or blame, skill or clumsiness. After seven days, I suddenly forget I have limbs or a body. At that moment, there is no court or state. My skill becomes whole, and all external distractions dissolve. Only then do I enter the mountain forests to observe the natural forms of trees, waiting until the perfect *jù* appears before me—only then do I set my hand to it. Otherwise, I stop. Thus, I unite Heaven with Heaven. This is why the finished vessel seems the work of spirits."

*A jù* is the frame that holds bells and drums.

The Duke believed no painted pattern could surpass it. He ordered Ji to drive a hundred intricate loops and return. Yan He encountered him and entered to say: "Ji’s horses will fail." The Duke kept this private, not wishing to make it known.

chunks.original_text: 工倕旋而盖规矩，而不应。 少焉，果败而反。 公曰何以知之？ 曰：其马力竭矣，而犹求焉，故曰败。 以手旋转而自中盖之规矩。 指与物化而不以心稽，故其灵台一而不桎，忘足屦之适也； 妄要带之适也； 知忘是非，心之适也； 不内变，不外从，事会之适也； 始乎适而未尝不适者，忘适之适也。 有孙休者，踵门而诧子扁庆子曰：休居乡不见谓不修，临难不见谓不勇。 然而田原不遇岁耕於野也，事君不遇世，宾槟同於乡里，逐於州部，则胡罪乎天哉？ 休恶音鸟此命也？ 扁子曰：子独不闻夫至人之自行邪？ 忘其肝胆，遗其耳目，芒然彷徨乎尘垢之外，逍遥乎无事之业，是谓为而不恃，长上声而不宰。 今汝饰知以惊愚，修身以明污，昭昭乎揭日月而行也。 汝得全而形躯，具而九窍，无中道夭於聋盲跛蹇而比於人数，亦幸矣，又何暇乎天之怨子间哉。 子往矣。 孙子出，扁子入。
chunks.translated_text:
The master craftsman Chui could turn his hand to match compass and square, yet it was not by calculation. Soon after, the chariot indeed failed and returned. The Duke asked, "How did you know?" He replied: "His horses’ strength was exhausted, yet he still demanded more—thus I said they would fail."

To turn the hand and naturally match compass and square means to transform with things without the mind’s interference. Thus, his spirit-terrace remains unified and unshackled, forgetting the comfort of feet and sandals, the fit of waistband and sash, the rightness of knowledge and judgment, the mind’s ease. Neither inwardly altered nor outwardly swayed, he meets events with perfect accord. From the first step of ease, he never departs from ease—this is the ease of forgetting ease.

There was a man named Sun Xiu who came to Master Bian Qingzi’s door and exclaimed: "Though I dwell in my village, none call me unrefined; though I face peril, none call me cowardly. Yet when I till the fields, the years do not favor me; when I serve a lord, the age does not favor me. Cast out by my village, driven from my district—what offense have I given Heaven? Why has fate treated me thus?" Master Bian replied: "Have you not heard of the Perfect Man’s way of conduct? He forgets his liver and gall, leaves behind his ears and eyes, wanders in boundless vagueness beyond the dust and grime, roams freely in the work of no-occupation—this is called acting without reliance, leading without domination. Now you adorn your knowledge to startle the foolish, cultivate your person to expose others’ flaws, and stride forth as if bearing the sun and moon. You have preserved your bodily form intact, kept all nine orifices whole, and avoided midway afflictions like deafness, blindness, lameness, or deformity to be counted among men—you are already fortunate. Why then do you have leisure to complain of Heaven’s injustice? Begone!"

Sun Xiu departed, and Master Bian entered.

After a while, he sat gazing upward and sighed. A disciple asked: "Master, why do you sigh?"

Master Bian replied: "Just now, Sun Xiu came, and I spoke to him of the Perfect Man’s virtue. I fear he was startled and may fall into confusion."

The disciple said: "Not so. If Sun Xiu’s words were right and yours wrong, he would not be confused by what is right. If Sun Xiu’s words were wrong and yours right, he was already confused when he came—what fault is that of yours?"

Master Bian said: "Not so. Once there was a bird that alighted in the outskirts of Lu. The Lord of Lu delighted in it, prepared a grand feast to entertain it, and performed the *Nine Shao* to please it. The bird grew anxious, sorrowful, and dizzy, and dared not eat or drink. This is called nourishing a bird with what nourishes oneself. As for nourishing a bird as a bird ought to be nourished, one should let it roost in deep forests, drift upon rivers and lakes, feed on whatever it encounters, and rest on level ground. Now Sun Xiu is a man of narrow understanding and scant knowledge. When I spoke to him of the Perfect Man’s virtue, it was like burdening a field mouse with chariots and horses, or delighting a sparrow with bells and drums—how could he not be startled?"*

*Kuan* means "small opening"; *qi* means "to open." *Kuanqi* describes one of limited vision.

chunks.original_text: 外篇山木 庄子行於山中，见大木，枝叶盛茂。 伐木者止其旁而不取也。 问其故，曰； 无所可用。 庄子曰：此木以不材得终其天年。 夫子出於山，舍於故人之家。 故人喜，命竖子杀雁而烹之。 竖子请曰：其一能鸣，其一不能呜，请奚杀？ 主人曰：杀不能鸣者。 明日，弟子问於庄子曰：昨日山中之木，以不材得终其天年； 今主人之雁，以不材死。 先生将何处？ 庄子笑曰：周将处夫材不材之间。 材与不材之间，似之而非也，故未免乎累。 若夫乘道德而浮游则不然，无誉无訾，一龙一蛇，与时俱化，而无肯专为。 一上一下，以和为量，浮游乎万物之祖。 物物而不物於物，则胡可得而累邪？ 此神农、黄帝之法则也。 若夫万物之情，人伦之传，则不然。 合则离，成则毁，廉则挫，尊则议，有为则亏，贤则谋，不肖则欺。 胡可得而必乎哉？ 悲夫，弟子志之，其唯道德之乡乎。 贤者尽心以谋事，而小人反奸诈以肆欺。 市南宜僚见鲁侯，鲁侯有忧色。 市南子曰：君有忧色，何也？ 鲁侯曰：吾学先王之道，修先君之业； 吾敬鬼尊贤； 亲而行之，无须臾离居。 然不免於患，吾是以忧。 市南子曰：君之除患之术浅矣。 夫丰狐文豹，栖於山林，伏於岩穴，静也； 夜行昼居，戒也； 虽饥渴隐约，犹且胥疏於江湖之上而求食焉，定也。 然且不免於罔罗机辟之患，是何罪之有哉？ 其皮为之灾也。 今鲁国独非君之皮邪？ 吾愿君刳形去皮，酒心去欲，而游於无人之野。 胥，相也。 疏，远也。 虽饥渴隐约，犹且相远於江湖之上而求食，言只在山林不肯出江湖之上求食也。 南越有邑焉，名为建德之国。 其民愚而朴，少私而寡欲； 知作而不知藏，与而不求其报； 不知义之所适，不知礼之所将。
chunks.translated_text:
**Outer Chapters: The Mountain Tree**

When Master Zhuang was traveling through the mountains, he saw a great tree with luxuriant branches and leaves. A woodcutter stood beside it but did not fell it. Asking the reason, he was told, "It is of no use." Master Zhuang said, "This tree, by being useless, has lived out its natural span."

Emerging from the mountains, he lodged at the house of an old friend. The friend, delighted, ordered a servant to kill a goose and cook it. The servant asked, "One can caw, the other cannot— which should we kill?" The host replied, "Kill the one that cannot caw."

The next day, a disciple asked Master Zhuang, "Yesterday, the tree in the mountains lived out its natural span by being useless; today, the host’s goose died for being useless. Where will you, Master, take your stand?" Master Zhuang laughed and said, "I will stand between usefulness and uselessness. Yet between usefulness and uselessness—though it seems so—it is not so, and thus one is not free from entanglement. But if one rides the Dao and floats upon virtue, it is otherwise: neither praised nor blamed, now dragon, now serpent, transforming with the times, never clinging to one form. Rising and falling, taking harmony as measure, drifting upon the ancestor of the ten thousand things. Treating things as things yet not being treated as a thing by them—how then could one be entangled? This is the method of Shennong and the Yellow Emperor.

As for the nature of the ten thousand things and the transmission of human relations, it is not so. Union leads to separation, completion to ruin, sharpness to blunting, honor to slander, action to loss, worthiness to schemes, unworthiness to deceit. How can one be certain of anything? Alas! Remember this, disciples: it is only in the realm of Dao and virtue.

The worthy exhaust their minds scheming over affairs, while petty men turn to cunning and deceit.

Jiananyi of Shinan visited the Lord of Lu, who wore a troubled expression. Jiananyi asked, "My lord, why this troubled look?" The Lord of Lu replied, "I study the Way of the former kings, cultivate the undertakings of my predecessors; I revere ghosts and honor the worthy; I practice this without the slightest lapse. Yet I cannot escape misfortune—this is why I am troubled."

Jiananyi said, "My lord’s method of avoiding misfortune is shallow. The sleek fox and the patterned leopard dwell in the mountains and forests, crouch in caves and cliffs—this is stillness. They move by night and rest by day—this is vigilance. Though hungry and thirsty, in straitened circumstances, they still keep their distance upon the rivers and lakes while seeking food—this is steadfastness. Yet they cannot escape the calamity of nets and traps. What crime have they committed? Their skins bring disaster upon them. Is not the state of Lu your lordship’s skin? I wish you would carve away your form, shed your skin, wash your heart, cast off desire, and wander in the wilds where no man dwells."

*Xu* means "to assist"; *shu* means "to distance." Though hungry and thirsty, in straitened circumstances, they still keep their distance upon the rivers and lakes while seeking food—this means they remain in the mountains and forests, refusing to venture upon the rivers and lakes to seek food.

In the southern lands there is a city called the State of Establishing Virtue. Its people are simple and guileless, with few private interests and scant desires. They know how to work but not how to hoard; they give without seeking repayment. They do not know where duty leads, nor where ritual is headed.

chunks.original_text: 猖狂妄行，乃蹈乎大方。 其生可乐，其死可葬。 吾愿君去国捐俗，与道相辅而行。 君曰：彼其道远而险，又有江山，我无舟车，奈何？ 市南子曰：君无形倨，无留居，以为君车。 君曰：彼其道幽远而无人，吾谁与为邻？ 吾无粮，我无食，安得而至焉？ 市南子曰：少君之费，寡君之欲，虽无粮而乃足。 君其涉於江而浮於海，望之而不见其崖，愈往而不知其所穷。 送君者自崖而反。 君自此远矣。 自南越有邑焉至此，是后人参入，且文字浅陋，必非庄语。 故有人者累，见有於人者忧。 故尧非有人，非见有於人也。 吾愿去君之累，除君之忧，而独与道游於大莫之国。 方舟而济於河，有虚船来触舟，虽有褊心之人不怒。 有一人在其上，则呼张歙之。 一呼而不闻，再呼而不闻，於是三呼邪，则必以恶声随之。 向也不怒而今也怒，向也虚而今也实。 人能虚已以游世，其孰能害之。 北宫奢为卫灵公赋敛以为锺，为坛乎郭门之外。 三月而成上下之县。 王子庆忌见而问焉，曰：子何术之设？ 奢曰：一之间无敢设也。 奢闻之：既雕既琢，复归於朴。 侗乎其无识，倘乎其怠疑。 萃乎芒乎，其送往而迎来。 来者勿禁，往者勿止。 从其强梁，随其曲传，因其自穷。 故朝夕赋敛而毫毛不挫，而况有大涂者乎。 道一而已，若有作为便贰之以二矣。 故曰一之间无敢设也。 侗乎，无识之貌。 倘乎，无心之貌。 萃乎芒乎，如物之丛生而无心也。 强梁，不顺之人。 委曲依传之人，一听其自然。 因其自穷者，因其自至则受之。 不挫者，不损也。 大涂者，大道也。 赋敛之事，且然况以大道治天下乎。 孔子围於陈蔡之间，七日不火食。 太公任往吊之，曰子几死乎？ 曰：然。 子恶死乎？ 曰：然。 任曰：予尝言不死之道。 东海有鸟焉。 其名曰意怠。 其为鸟也，翂翂翐翐，而似无能； 引援而飞，迫胁而栖； 进不敢为前，退不敢为后； 食不敢先尝，必取其绪。 是故其行列不斥，而外人卒不得害，是以兔於患。 直木先伐，甘井先竭。 子其意者饰知以惊愚，修身以明污，昭昭乎如揭日月而行，故不免也。 昔者吾闻之大成之人曰：自伐者无功，功成者堕，名成者亏。 孰能去功与名而还与众人。 道流而不明居，得行而不名处； 纯纯常常，乃比於狂削迹损执，不为功名。 是故无责於人，人亦无责焉。 至人不闻，子何喜哉。 孔子曰：善哉。 辞其交游，去其子弟，逃於大泽，衣裘褐，食杼栗，入兽不乱群，入鸟不乱行。 鸟兽不恶，而况人乎？ 孔子问子桑雽音户曰：吾再逐於鲁，伐树於宋，削迹於卫，穷於商周，围於陈蔡之间。 吾犯此数患，亲交益疏，徒友益散，何与？ 子桑雽曰：子独不闻假人之亡与？ 假，托人而得逃。 林回弃千金之璧，负赤子而趋。 或曰：为其布与布货也？ 赤子之布寡矣； 为其累与？ 赤子之累多矣。 弃千金之璧，负赤子而趋，何也？ 林回曰：彼以利合，此以天属也。 夫以利合者，迫穷祸患害相弃也； 以天属者，迫穷祸患害相收也。 夫相收之与相弃远矣，且君子之交淡若水，小人之交甘若醴。 君子淡以亲，小人甘以绝，彼无故以合者，则无故以离。 孔子曰：敬闻命矣。 徐行翔佯而归，绝学捐书，弟子无挹於前，其爱益加进。 异日，桑雽又曰：舜之将死，真泠禹曰：汝戒之哉。

The reckless and wayward tread the great square of the Dao. Their lives may be joyful, their deaths may be buried. I wish you would abandon your state, cast off custom, and walk in mutual support with the Way.

You say: "That Way is distant and perilous, with rivers and mountains in between. I have no boat or carriage—what then?"
Master South-of-Market replies: "Do not cling to form or pride, do not linger in one place, and take this as your carriage."

You say: "That Way is secluded and remote, with no one there—with whom shall I be neighbors? I have no provisions, no food—how can I reach it?"
Master South-of-Market replies: "Reduce your expenses, diminish your desires, and though you have no grain, you will find sufficiency. Cross the river and float upon the sea; gaze upon it and you will not see its shore. The farther you go, the less you will know its end. Those who see you off will turn back from the shore—from then on, you will be far away."

From the State of Establishing Virtue in the south to this point, later generations have interpolated these words, crude and shallow, surely not the authentic voice of Zhuangzi.

Thus, to possess others is a burden; to be possessed by others is a sorrow. Therefore, Yao neither possessed others nor was possessed by them. I wish to relieve you of your burdens, remove your sorrows, and wander alone with the Way in the boundless realm.

When a double-hulled boat crosses a river, an empty boat drifts into it—even a man of narrow heart would not grow angry. But if there were a man aboard, he would shout to steer it away. If the first shout goes unheard, he shouts again; if still unheard, he curses in anger. Before, he was not angry, but now he is—before, the boat was empty, but now it is full. If a man can empty himself and wander through the world, who can harm him?

When Beigong She levied taxes for Duke Ling of Wei to cast bells, he built an altar outside the outer gate of the capital. In three months, the upper and lower chimes were complete. Prince Qingji saw this and asked: "What method did you employ?"
She replied: "In the space of unity, I dared not impose any method. I have heard: after carving and polishing, return to simplicity. Vast and unknowing, drifting and hesitant, like plants growing wild and without intent—sending off the departing, welcoming the arriving. Let those who come not be barred, let those who go not be stopped. Follow the strong and unyielding, adapt to the crooked and compliant, and let them reach their own end. Thus, though taxes were levied day and night, not a hair was harmed—how much more so for those who tread the great path?"

The Way is one alone; if you act with purpose, you divide it into two. Thus, in the space of unity, I dared not impose any method.

Vast and unknowing, drifting and without intent, like plants growing wild—this is the appearance of having no mind. The strong and unyielding are those who do not follow; those who are crooked and compliant simply follow their nature. To "let them reach their own end" means to accept what comes of itself. "Not harmed" means not diminished. The "great path" is the great Way. If even tax collection can be so, how much more so governing the world by the great Way?

Confucius was besieged between Chen and Cai, going seven days without cooked food. Taigong Ren went to console him, asking: "Are you near death?"
"Yes," Confucius replied.
"Do you hate death?"
"Yes."

Taigong Ren said: "Let me speak to you of the way of not dying. In the Eastern Sea there is a bird called *Yidai*. As a bird, it is slow and sluggish, appearing incapable. It flies only when supported, perches only when pressed. It does not dare to advance first or retreat last; it does not dare to eat before others, but must take the leftovers. Thus, it is never driven from the flock, and others never harm it—so it escapes misfortune. The straight tree is the first felled; the sweet well is the first drained. You, I fear, adorn your knowledge to startle the foolish, cultivate yourself to expose the corrupt, shining brightly like one who carries the sun and moon in procession—how could you escape harm?

Long ago, I heard from a man of great completion: 'Those who boast of themselves achieve no merit; those who achieve merit fall; those who achieve fame lose it. Who can relinquish merit and fame and return to the common people?' The Way flows but does not dwell in fame; it acts but does not claim a place. Pure and constant, it is like one who is mad, erasing traces and diminishing attachments, not seeking merit or fame. Thus, it demands nothing of others, and others demand nothing of it. The perfected person does not strive—why do you delight in this?"

Confucius said: "Excellent!" He then parted from his friends and disciples, fled to the great marsh, wore coarse cloth and furs, ate acorns and chestnuts, and entered among beasts without disturbing their herds, among birds without disrupting their flocks. Birds and beasts did not shun him—how much less would men?

Confucius asked Zisang Hu: "I was twice banished from Lu, had a tree felled in Song, was forced to erase my tracks in Wei, was impoverished in Shang and Zhou, and besieged between Chen and Cai. I have suffered these many misfortunes, my close friends growing more distant, my followers scattering—why is this?"

Zisang Hu replied: "Have you not heard of the escape of the man from Jia? Jia was a man who relied on others to flee. Lin Hui abandoned a jade disc worth a thousand gold pieces to carry a baby on his back and run. Someone asked: 'Was it for the sake of its value? The baby’s value is slight. Was it for the burden? The baby’s burden is great. Why abandon a jade disc worth a thousand gold pieces to carry a baby and run?' Lin Hui said: 'That was bound by profit; this is bound by heaven. Those bound by profit abandon each other in straitened circumstances, misfortune, and harm; those bound by heaven gather together in straitened circumstances, misfortune, and harm. The difference between gathering and abandoning is vast. Moreover, the friendship of a gentleman is as bland as water; the friendship of a petty man is as sweet as wine. The gentleman’s blandness brings closeness; the petty man’s sweetness brings estrangement. Those who come together without cause will part without cause.'"

Confucius said: "I respectfully receive your instruction." He then walked slowly and leisurely home, abandoned his studies, discarded his books, and his disciples no longer vied for his attention before him—yet their love for him grew deeper.

Another day, Zisang Hu said: "When Shun was about to die, he earnestly warned Yu: 'Be vigilant!'"

chunks.original_text: 形莫若缘，情莫若率。 缘则不离，率则不劳。 不离不劳，则不求文以待形。 固不待物。 真泠禹是人名，汝指舜也。 庄子衣大布而补之，正緳苦结切，带也系履而过魏王。 魏王曰：何先生之惫邪？ 庄子曰：贫也，非惫也。 士有道德不能行，惫也； 衣弊履穿，贫也，非惫也，此所谓非遭时也。 王独不见夫腾猿乎？ 其得柟梓豫章也，揽蔓其枝而王去声长上声其间，虽羿、逢蒙不能眄睨也。 及其得柘棘枳枸音矩之间也，危行侧视，振动悼栗，此筋骨非有加急而不柔也，处执不便，朱足以逞其能也。 今处昏上乱相之间而欲无惫，奚可得邪？ 此比干之见剖心征也夫。 正緳，正其带也。 孔子穷於陈蔡之间，七日不火食。 左据槁木，右击槁枝，而歌焱氏之风，有其具而无其数，有其声而无宫角。 木声与人声，犁 犹犁者其土，释然也。 然有当於人之心。 颜回端拱还目而窥之。 仲尼恐其广己而造大也，爱己而造哀也，曰：回，无受天损易，无受人益难。 无始而非卒也，人与天一也。 夫今之歌者其谁乎？ 回曰：敢问无受天损易。 仲尼曰：饥渴寒暑，穷桎不行，天地之行也，运物之泄也，言与之偕逝之谓也。 为人臣者，不敢去之。 执臣之道犹若是，而况乎所以待天乎。 饥渴寒暑，穷困不通，皆天地之气流行所以运动万物发泄而不可遏者。 人欲免乎此，必须天地之气不行而后可，但当与之偕往可也。 人臣视君犹天地，亦惟顺之而已矣。 何谓无受人益难？ 仲尼曰：始用四达，爵禄并至而不穷。 物之所利，乃非己也，吾命有在外者也。 始得见用之时，并无窒碍。 爵禄穹隆非不可喜，然鞠躬尽瘁，但所以利物而已。 其於己何与？ 吾命有在於此之外者。 君子不为盗，贤人不为窃，吾若取之何哉？ 故曰：鸟莫知於鷾鸸，目之所不宜处不给视，虽落其实，弃之而走。 其畏人也而袭诸人间。 社稷存焉耳。 鷾鸸，燕也。 不给，不暇也。 实，卯也。 社稷，春秋祭社稷之时也。 燕於人家不可处者不暇视，虽落其卵，弃之不复顾。 其所以然者，畏人故也。 其袭处於人间不过祭社稷之时存焉耳。 燕以春社来，秋社去。 《春秋传》曰：无钟鼓曰袭。 此不过眼前说话，而解者自为迂僻可笑。 类此甚多。 何谓无始而非卒？ 仲尼曰：化其万物而不知其禅去声之者，焉知其所终？ 焉知其所始？ 正而待之而已耳。

Shape should follow its natural course; emotions should follow their true nature. Following the natural course prevents separation; following true nature prevents exhaustion. Without separation or exhaustion, one does not seek adornment to match form. Thus, one does not depend on external things.

Zhenling Yu is a person’s name, and "you" refers to Shun.

Zhuangzi wore coarse cloth patched with hemp, tied his shoes with rough cords, and passed by King Wei. The king said: "Why is the Master so weary?" Zhuangzi replied: "It is poverty, not weariness. A scholar who possesses the Dao and virtue yet cannot put them into practice—that is weariness. Worn-out clothes and tattered shoes are poverty, not weariness. This is what is called not encountering the right time. Has Your Majesty never seen the leaping monkeys? When they find themselves among nanmu, catalpa, and camphor trees, they grasp the vines and swing through the branches, reigning supreme—even Yi or Feng Meng could not take aim at them. Yet when they find themselves among thorn bushes, brambles, and jujube thickets, they move cautiously, glancing about in fear, trembling with dread. This is not because their sinews and bones have suddenly stiffened, but because their position is unfavorable, and they cannot fully display their abilities. Now, living amid a benighted ruler and chaotic ministers, how can one avoid weariness? This is like the fate of Bi Gan, whose heart was cut out as proof!"

*Zhengxi* means to straighten one’s sash.

Confucius was stranded between Chen and Cai, going seven days without cooked food. Leaning on a withered tree, he struck its dry branches and sang the airs of the *Yan* clan. There was the form of the music but not its precise structure, the sound but not its proper notes. The sound of the wood and the human voice blended like a plow turning the soil—loose and free—yet it resonated with the hearts of others. Yan Hui stood with folded hands, turning his gaze to observe. Fearing that Yan Hui might overreach in his admiration or grow sorrowful out of affection, Confucius said: "Hui, it is easy to accept what heaven diminishes, but difficult to accept what others bestow. There is no beginning that is not also an end—humanity and heaven are one. Who is it that sings now?"

Yan Hui said: "May I ask why it is easy to accept what heaven diminishes?" Confucius replied: "Hunger, thirst, cold, and heat—when one is trapped and cannot move—are the workings of heaven and earth, the outflow of the movement of things. To speak of going along with them is to say one moves with them. As a minister, one does not dare to depart from this. If even the way of serving a ruler is like this, how much more so the way of awaiting heaven? Hunger, thirst, cold, and heat—when one is trapped and cannot move—are the flowing of heaven and earth’s *qi*, the movement and release of the myriad things, which cannot be stopped. To wish to avoid this, one would have to halt the *qi* of heaven and earth—one can only go along with it. A minister regards his ruler as heaven and earth; he must simply follow."

"What do you mean by it being difficult to accept what others bestow?" Confucius said: "At the outset, one’s path opens in all four directions, and ranks and emoluments arrive without end. What others find beneficial is not one’s own—one’s fate lies beyond such things. When one first gains employment, there are no obstacles. Ranks and emoluments may be grand and not without appeal, but one exhausts oneself in service only to benefit others—what does it have to do with oneself? One’s fate lies beyond such things. The gentleman does not steal; the worthy does not pilfer. What would I take from them? Thus it is said: No bird is wiser than the swallow. Where its eyes should not linger, it does not glance; even if its eggs fall, it abandons them and flees. Though it fears humans, it nests among them—only for the sake of the altars of soil and grain.

*The swallow* is the swallow. *Does not glance* means it has no time. *Eggs* refers to its brood. *Altars of soil and grain* refers to the spring and autumn sacrifices to the gods of soil and grain. The swallow does not linger where it should not nest in human dwellings; even if its eggs fall, it abandons them without a backward glance. The reason is its fear of humans. Its nesting among humans only occurs during the sacrifices to the altars of soil and grain. Swallows come at the spring sacrifice and depart at the autumn sacrifice. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* states: 'Without bells and drums, it is called *stealth*.' This is merely a passing remark, yet commentators have made it needlessly abstruse and laughable—there are many such cases.

"What do you mean by 'there is no beginning that is not also an end'?" Confucius said: "When the myriad things transform, one does not know who succeeds them—how can one know their end? How can one know their beginning? One simply aligns with them and awaits."

chunks.original_text: 何谓人与天一邪？ 仲尼曰：有人，天也； 有天，亦天也。 人之不能有天，性也。 圣人晏然体逝而终矣。 凡事非人所能为，有人做得底，皆天也。 而有天所为者，亦天也。 凡人之所以不能自有，皆天性之自然也。 圣人惟与天一故。 晏然体逝，安然身与之俱逝也。 庄周游乎雕陵之樊，睹一异鹊自南来者。 翼广光去七尺，目大运寸，感周之额飞得低，而集於栗林。 庄周曰：此何鸟哉。 翼殷大也不逝，目大不睹。 寨裳躩步，执弹而留之。 睹一蝉方得美荫而忘其身。 螳螂执翳而搏之，见得而忘其形。 异鹊从而利之，见利而忘其真。 庄周怵然曰：噫。 物固相累，二类相召也。 捐弹而反走，虞人逐而谇骂之之。 庄周反入，三月不庭不出庭。 兰且音徂从而问之：夫子何为顷间甚不庭乎？ 庄周曰：吾守形而忘身，观於浊水而迷於清渊。 且吾闻诸夫子曰：入其俗，从其俗。 今吾游於雕陵而忘吾身，异鹊感吾额，游於栗林而忘真。 栗林虞人以吾为戮辱也，吾所以不庭也。 阳子之宋，宿於逆旅。 逆旅人有妾二人，其一人美，其一人恶。 恶者贵而美者贱。 阳子问其故，逆旅小子对曰：其美者自美，吾不知其美也； 其恶者自恶，吾不知其恶也。 阳子曰：弟子记之：行贤而去自贤之行，安往而不爱哉。 人但当行贤德之事，则於人何所不爱。 南华真经循本卷之十九竟 南华真经循本卷之二十

"What does it mean for humans and Heaven to be one?" Confucius said: "Where there is humanity, there is Heaven; where there is Heaven, there is also Heaven. That humans cannot possess Heaven is their nature. The sage, at ease, embodies the passing and comes to an end. In all matters beyond human capacity, whatever humans accomplish is Heaven. And what Heaven accomplishes is also Heaven. That humans cannot possess themselves is simply the spontaneity of Heavenly nature. Only the sage is one with Heaven—at ease, embodying the passing, calmly allowing body and self to pass away together."

Zhuang Zhou wandered near the fence of Carved Mound and saw an unusual magpie coming from the south. Its wings spanned seven feet in breadth, its eyes measured an inch in circumference. It brushed against Zhou’s forehead in flight, descended, and alighted in a chestnut grove. Zhuang Zhou said: "What bird is this? Its wings are vast yet it does not fly far; its eyes are large yet it does not see clearly." He tucked up his robe, strode forward, took up his sling, and waited. He saw a cicada enjoying the fine shade and forgetting its own form. A mantis, seizing the opportunity, struck at it, seeing only its gain and forgetting its own shape. The unusual magpie, drawn by profit, seized the chance, seeing only the advantage and forgetting its true nature. Zhuang Zhou, startled, said: "Alas! Things indeed entangle one another—two kinds summon each other." He cast aside his sling and turned to flee, but the gamekeeper pursued him with shouts and curses.

Zhuang Zhou returned home and for three months did not step into the courtyard. Lan Ju approached and asked: "Master, why have you been so withdrawn lately?" Zhuang Zhou replied: "I guarded my form and forgot my self; I gazed upon muddy waters and became lost in clear depths. Moreover, I have heard from my master: 'Enter their customs, follow their customs.' Now I wandered in Carved Mound and forgot my self; the unusual magpie brushed my forehead, and I wandered in the chestnut grove and forgot my true nature. The gamekeeper of the chestnut grove took me for a disgrace—this is why I have withdrawn."

Yang Zi traveled to Song and lodged at an inn. The innkeeper had two concubines—one beautiful, the other ugly. The ugly one was honored, while the beautiful one was slighted. Yang Zi asked the reason, and the innkeeper’s servant replied: "The beautiful one is self-aware of her beauty, so I do not recognize her beauty; the ugly one is self-aware of her ugliness, so I do not recognize her ugliness." Yang Zi said: "Disciples, take note: act with virtue and abandon the conduct of self-regard—wherever you go, will you not be loved? One should simply practice virtuous deeds—then how could one fail to be loved by others?"

chunks.original_text: 庐陵竹峰罗勉道述门人彭祥点校 外篇田子方 田子方侍坐魏文侯，数称溪工#1。 文侯曰：溪工，子之师邪？ 子方曰：非也，无择之里人也。 称道数当去声，故无择称之。 文侯曰：然则子无师邪？ 子方曰：有。 曰：子之师谁邪？ 子方曰：东郭顺子。 文侯曰：然则夫子何故未尝称之？ 子方曰：其为人也真。 人貌而天虚，缘而葆真，清而容物。 三句文法一同。 虽人之貌而合乎自然之天，虽虚以顺物而自葆其真，虽清而能容物。 物无道，正容以悟之，使人之意也消。 横逆之来，惟正其在我，以悟之而其意自消释。 无择何足以称之。 子方出，文侯傥然，终日不言。 召前立臣而语之曰：远矣，全德之君子指顺子。 始吾以圣知之言、仁义之行为至矣。 吾闻子方之师，吾形解而不欲动，口钳而不欲言。 吾所学者，真土梗耳。 夫魏真为我累耳。 温伯雪子适齐，舍於鲁。 鲁人有请见之者，温伯雪子曰：不可。 吾闻中国之君子，明乎礼义而陋於知人心。 吾不欲见也。 至於齐，反舍於鲁，是人也又请见。 温伯雪子曰：往也蕲见我，今也又蕲见我，是必有以振起发也我也。 出而见客，入而叹。 明日见客，又入而叹。 其仆曰：每见之客也，必入而叹，何邪？ 曰：吾固告子矣：中国之民，明乎礼义而陋乎知人心。 昔之见我者，进退一成规、一成矩，从容一若龙、一若虎。 其谏我也似子，其道导也我也似父，是以叹也。 仲尼见之而不言。 子路曰：吾子欲见温伯雪子久矣。 见之而不言，何邪？ 仲尼曰：若夫人者，目击而道存矣，亦不可以容声矣。 目击而道存者，目一加而道即存。 不待详察也。 颜渊问於仲尼曰：夫子步亦步，夫子趋亦趋,夫子驰亦驰，夫子奔逸绝尘而回瞠若乎后矣。 夫子曰：回，何谓邪？ 曰：夫子步亦步也，夫子趋亦趋也，夫子辩亦辩也； 夫子驰亦驰也，夫子言道，回亦言道也； 以下句解上五句。 及奔逸绝尘而回瞠若乎后者，夫子不言而信，不比而周，无器而民蹈乎前，而不知其所以然而已矣。 仲尼曰：恶！ 可不察与！ 夫哀莫大於心死，而人死亦次之。 日出东方而入於西极，万物莫不比方，有目有趾者，待是而后成功。 是出则存，是入则亡。 万物亦然，有待也而死，有待也而生。 吾一受其成形，而不化以待尽。 效物而动，日夜无隙，不知其所终。 熏然其成形，知命不能规乎其前。 丘以是日祖。 吾终身与女交一臂而失之，可不哀与？ 哀颜渊也女殆着乎吾所以着也。 彼已尽矣，而女求之以为有，是求为於唐肆也。 吾服，女也甚忘； 女服，吾也亦甚忘。 虽然，女奚患焉？ 虽忘乎故吾，吾有不忘者存。 瞠若乎后者，直视而不能追及也。 无器而民蹈乎前者，无鼓动民之具而民自舞蹈乎前也。 颜渊不知其所以然，故仲尼曰：恶。 可不察与？ 其所以不知者，人惟执着死其心故尔。 因以日为喻，万物莫不视日之出入而作息，其有待而生死亦然。 仲尼不过效物而动，与之相为不息，任其成形亦不论命，但以此日往而已。 熏然者，如气之熏烝而成也。 吾终身与汝犹吾无行而不与二三子之与，吾终身以此道示汝，今以为不可及，是犹不曾两臂相交，只交得一臂而相失，岂不可哀哉。 汝所言者，时，见吾之可见者耳。 着，见也。

**External Chapters: Tián Zǐfāng**

Tián Zǐfāng attended upon Marquis Wén of Wèi and repeatedly praised Xī Gōng. The Marquis said: "Xī Gōng—is he your teacher?" Zǐfāng replied: "No. He is but a villager of Wúzé. His praises were so apt that Wúzé could not but speak of him." The Marquis said: "Then do you have no teacher?" Zǐfāng said: "I do." The Marquis asked: "Who is your teacher?" Zǐfāng said: "Dōngguō Shùnzǐ." The Marquis said: "Then why have you never spoken of him?" Zǐfāng said: "His way of being is true. His appearance is human, yet his nature is of Heaven; he follows things while preserving his authenticity; he is pure yet embraces all. Though he bears a human form, he accords with Heaven’s spontaneity; though empty, he follows things while guarding his truth; though clear, he contains all things. When beings lack the Dao, he meets them with upright bearing to awaken them, dissolving their intentions. When confronted with perversity, he simply rectifies what lies within himself, and their resistance melts away. How could Wúzé be worthy of speaking of him?"

Zǐfāng departed. The Marquis, lost in thought, remained silent the whole day. Summoning the ministers who stood before him, he said: "Far indeed is the gentleman of perfect virtue! At first, I thought the words of sagely wisdom and the conduct of benevolence and righteousness were the ultimate. But when I heard of Zǐfāng’s teacher, my form dissolved and I had no desire to move; my mouth was sealed and I had no desire to speak. What I have learned is but a clay figurine. Truly, Wèi has been a burden to me."

Wēnbó Xuězǐ traveled to Qí and lodged in Lǔ. A man of Lǔ requested an audience with him. Wēnbó Xuězǐ said: "I cannot. I have heard that the gentlemen of the Central States are enlightened in ritual and righteousness but coarse in understanding the human heart. I do not wish to meet him." When he arrived in Qí and returned to lodge in Lǔ, the same man again requested an audience. Wēnbó Xuězǐ said: "Before, he sought to see me; now, he seeks to see me again—he must have some inspiration to stir me." He went out to meet the guest, then returned and sighed. The next day, he met the guest again and returned, sighing once more. His servant said: "Every time you meet this guest, you return and sigh. Why?" He replied: "I told you before: the people of the Central States are enlightened in ritual and righteousness but coarse in understanding the human heart. The one who saw me earlier advanced and retreated like a compass or square, moved with the composure of a dragon or tiger. When he admonished me, it was like a son; when he guided me, it was like a father. That is why I sighed."

Confucius met him and did not speak. Zǐlù said: "Master, you have long wished to see Wēnbó Xuězǐ. Now that you have met him, you do not speak. Why?" Confucius said: "In such a man, the Dao is present at a glance—how could words contain it? The Dao is present the moment one’s gaze falls upon him; there is no need for careful examination."

Yán Yuān asked Confucius: "When the Master walks, I walk; when the Master hurries, I hurry; when the Master runs, I run; when the Master dashes away, leaving no trace of dust, I can only stare blankly behind." Confucius said: "Yuān, what do you mean?" He replied: "When the Master walks, I walk; when the Master hurries, I hurry; when the Master debates, I debate; when the Master runs, I run; when the Master speaks of the Dao, I speak of the Dao. Yet when you dash away, leaving no trace of dust, I can only stare blankly behind. For the Master speaks without needing to establish trust, unites without needing to form bonds, and though without instruments, the people gather before you—yet I do not know why."

Confucius said: "Alas! How can you not examine this? There is no greater sorrow than the death of the heart, and the death of the body is secondary to it. The sun rises in the east and sets in the westernmost reaches; all things follow its pattern. Those with eyes and feet depend on it to complete their tasks. When it rises, they exist; when it sets, they perish. All things are thus: some depend on it to die, some depend on it to live. Once I received this completed form, I did not change but awaited its end. I move in response to things, day and night without pause, not knowing where it will end. My form was completed as if by the steaming of qi, and even knowing fate, I cannot plan for what lies ahead. I have followed this path daily. My whole life, I have extended my arm to you, yet you have lost it—is this not sorrowful? I grieve for you, Yuān. You cling to what I cling to. He has already exhausted it, yet you seek it as if it still exists—this is like searching for something in an abandoned marketplace. What I wear, you forget; what you wear, I also forget. Yet why should you worry? Though you forget the old me, there is something in me that cannot be forgotten."

"Staring blankly behind" means gazing straight ahead yet unable to catch up. "Though without instruments, the people gather before you" means that without tools to stir the people, they dance before you of their own accord. Yán Yuān did not understand why, so Confucius said: "Alas! How can you not examine this?" The reason he did not understand was that he had fixed his heart upon death. Thus, he used the sun as a metaphor: all things follow the sun’s rising and setting in their work and rest, and their life and death likewise depend on it. Confucius merely moved in response to things, flowing with them without cease, accepting his completed form without discussing fate, simply proceeding day by day. "As if by steaming" means as if formed by the steaming of qi. My whole life, I have been with you as if I had no conduct apart from the others, yet you have taken what I showed you daily as unattainable. This is like never having clasped arms, only extending one arm before losing it—how could it not be sorrowful? What you spoke of was merely the timely, what you saw of me was only what could be seen. "Clinging" means seeing.

chunks.original_text: 彼，夫子自彼也。 彼以净尽空虚矣，而汝求之以为有，如求马於唐肆。 唐肆固卖马之处而岂常有马哉？ 《诗》云中唐有号。 注：中唐，为庭中路盖卖马之肆，庭中有路以便马之出入也。 《汉书》建章宫西有唐中数十里。 杨雄《羽猎赋》序云：甘露零其庭，醴泉流其唐。 班固《西都赋》：前唐中而浚大液。 服，佩服也。 吾佩服汝之言，与汝佩服吾之言皆当大忘之。 又恐颜渊患其终不及，虽然，汝何患焉，忘之中乃有不忘者存。 所忘者，执着也。 不忘者，至真也。 汝虽把吾之旧说忘之，若自有所得则有不忘者存矣。 孔子见老聃，老聃新沐，方将被发而乾，慹然似非人。 孔子便而待之待於偏处。 少焉见去声，曰：某也眩与？ 其信然与？ 向者先生形体掘若槁木，似遗物离人而立於独也。 老聃曰：吾游心於物之初。 孔子曰：何谓邪？ 曰：心困焉而不能知，口辟焉 读为辟邪之辟，必亦切。 口如被辟而不能言也。 而不能言，尝为女议乎其将： 将，将然也。 试为汝言其将然之初也。 至阴肃肃，至阳赫赫，肃肃出乎天，赫赫发乎地。 两者交通成和而物生焉，或为之纪而莫见其形。 消息满虚，一晦一明，日改月化，日有所为而莫见其功。 生有所乎萌，死有所乎归，始终相反乎无端，而莫知其所穷。 非是也，且孰为之宗。 孔子曰：请问游是。 老聃曰：夫得是至美至乐也。 得至美而游乎至乐。 谓之至人。 孔子曰：愿闻其方。 曰：草食之兽，不疾不恶也易薮； 水生之虫，不疾易水。 行小#2变而不失其大常也，喜恕哀乐不入於胸次。 夫天下也者，万物之所一也。 得其所一而同焉，则四支百体将为尘垢，而死生终始将为昼夜，而莫之能滑，而况得丧祸福之所介乎。 弃隶者若弃泥涂，知身贵於隶也。 贵在於我而不失於变。 且万化而未始有极也，夫孰足以患心。 已为道者解乎此。 亲自得道者，方能晓比也。 孔子曰：夫子德配天地，而犹假至言以修心。 古之君子，孰能说焉？ 说，音脱。 谁能免此也。 老聃曰：不然。 夫水之於汋也，无为而才自然矣； 至人之於德也，不修而物不能离焉。 若天之自高，地之自厚，日月之自明夫何修焉。 孔子出，以告颜回曰：丘之於道也，其犹酰鸡与。 微夫子之发吾覆也，吾不知天地之大全也。 庄子见鲁哀公，哀公曰：鲁多儒士，少为先生方者比也。 庄子曰：鲁少儒。 哀公曰：举鲁国而儒服，何谓少乎？ 庄子曰：周闻之：儒者冠圜冠者知天时，履句屦者知地形，缓佩玦者事至而断。 君子有其道者，未必为其服也； 为其服者，未必知其道也。 公固以为不然，何不号於国中曰：无此道而为此服者，其罪死。 於是哀公号之五日，而鲁国无敢儒服者。 独有一丈夫，儒服而立乎公门。 公即召而问以国事，千转万变而不穷。 庄子曰：以鲁国而儒者一人耳，可谓多乎。 百里奚爵禄不入於心，故饭牛而牛肥，使秦穆公忘其贱，与之政也。 有虞氏死生不入於心，故足以动人。 宋元君将画图，众史皆至，受揖而立，舐笔和墨，在外者半。 有一史后至者，儃然不趋，受揖不立，因之舍。 公使人视之，则解衣盘砖裸，君曰：可矣，是真画者也。 文王观於臧，见一丈夫钓，而其钓莫钓。 虽钓而不钓也。 非持其钓有钓者也，常钓也。
